title: As someon who plays mostly immobile champions
body:
This game isn't fun for me anymore. Period.

I enjoy a lot of immobile champions because they have a lot of unique features that separate them from other champions. From build paths to abilities, immobile champions feel more rewarding when played well. I feel like I did some cool shit as Nasus or Mordekaiser when I manage to flank from behind and separate the enemy team as Nasus with positioning and timing my rush. I feel awesome when I can successfully get an enemy ADC as my pet as Mordekaiser, which is actually hard as fuck to do. I feel awesome when I wait for the right moment as Olaf to pop ghost/ult and chain axes and dive an enemy carry. I feel awesome as Cho'Gath when I land a clutch rupture on someone by predicting where they'll jump to and feasting them to either kill them or force them out of the fight.

And that's why immobile champions like that are immobile. When played well and positioned properly, they have potentially game changing mechanics and features that can turn the tides of a fight. But that is slowly dwindling away if it hasn't alteady. As an immobile champion, you're late game fantasy that Riot loves to preach almost never exists. With spammable slows, spammable mobility, spammable cc on RANGED CHAMPIONS galore, I feel like half the time I'm just wasting time trying to play these champions. The risk I take for picking these champions doesn't really feel rewarding even when I perform well during their most exploitable times (lane phase mostly).

And then you get into other shit before a "late game fantasy" can even be realized. I love Mordekaiser, but I don't play him much anymore because it just feels pointless. So many junglers can show up to my lane and simply kill me by existing. Which I get that, he's immobile and he shoves, he has to have a weakness. But champions like Jarvan, Lee Sin, Vi, etc. make it to the point where they show up and you HAVE TO flash and thus, your lane is now over. Again, I fully understand this risk and that this is his counter play but taking this risk feels pointless because half the time, I get shut down in lane and the other half, when I do perform well and ward and keep gank free, I get cc'd once and instantly blow up. 

It's gotten to the point where only ranged adcs and a select few AP carries can only have a late game fantasy. Champions like Nasus, Tryndamere, Olaf, etc., who you look at and think "God damn, this guy gets items and he's terrifying" are shut down by the push of a button with slows, random CC and then on top of that, if they manage to break through this, their target just blinks away like nothing. So why bother? Just split push, towers can't kite. But that strategy is fucking lame. I don't want to afk split push, bring 2-3 people up to stop me and depend on my team to cash in on their over commitment to stopping me. That's lame for me, that's lame for my team, that's lame for the enemy team and that's lame for the guy I have to lane against because he can basically never leave. But what choice do I have? I don't want to play whatever fotm overtuned, random cc full, random mobility filled garbage of an excuse designed champion comes out next, I want to play the champions I enjoy playing so I have to adapt. And I have to adapt because directly and indirectly, they've had their late game fantasy taken away.

Anything tha threatens the greatness of adcs and those select few ap mids/assassins late game gets instantly crushed with nerfs. To the point that you don't want your champions to become popular, you know what will happen if they do. Why can't ranged adcs have their late game fantasy punished? Why can't some of the mid assassins and mages who can carry have their late game punished? Scratch that, most of them will have it punished. Itemization by far continues to favor ranged adcs late game, mid game and even early game. Sure, other classes get s few items here and there but it's not enough.

And what I'm saying about this whole late game fantasy and the risk/reward of picking some of these immobile, supposedly godlike late game champions has so many layers of shit that fucks them over, I don't even know where to begin or where to end. Actually, it basically ends at "who's adc is better late game and which adc plays better late game." But that's only a fraction of it. There's so much shit that involves this, from shit like Lee Sin, to poor itemization, to defensive itemization blowing ass and having few variety (mostly MR), to random max health % dmg galore, to random cc on everything new, to random mobility on everything new, random slows galore and the kitchen sink. It doesn't end and it only continues to get worse.

I realize this is hardly a coherent post. But im just so fed up with feeling like I play extremely well on these champions only to get outperformed by other shit because they simply have more stuff and random power thrown into their kits. So in the end, the tl;dr of this entire rant is that this game isn't fun for me anymore. And I hate saying that because I love League of Legends, but everything the balance team, new champion design team and itemization team has done has legit shit on the champions I play while throwing them random insignificant bones here and there. Pick this apart and rage at me as you will, I really don't care. I'm just fed up.

I could go on for pages about all the shit that frustrates me because as I said, there's so many layers to this that its honestly impossible for me to know where to start and where to begin.

As for split pushing, I like it as a strategy to an extent. But when it's afk split pushing, both the person doing it and the person defending it have their in game choices robbed from them. The split pusher is doing it because he literally can't do anything else and the one fighting it can't leave or his inhib is gone by 20 minutes. Riot talks about people having choices but split pushers have no choice for the most part, they can't do anything else. And that is honestly fucking lame.

I completely understand what you mean. I for one am a huge fan of both Nasus and Morde. Morgana was my first mained champion, and I still love her to this day. 

However, even though that I am a fan of the low mobility champs as well, I have also taught myself how to play with some decently mobile champs as well. Diana is a champ that I can wreck the enemy team with, and although she is classified as a fighter, I play her more as an assassin. Since I have played her so much, I have learned to be patient with her, choose the right time and the right target to go in on. In fact, the last game I played with her, I impressed even myself. I let the tanks engage, soak up most of the damage and cc, then went onto the fed enemy Riven who probably didn't even notice I was on her until she was dead. We won the game after that fight.

This patience has transfered quite nicely over to the immobile champions. You can't get onto your opponents, so you have to wait for them to come to you, especially when playing Morde. You don't have to split push, you can push with your team, and if the enemy engages onto to you, you can then charge the backline and cause as much chaos as possible. The more patience you have, the more objectives you will take, and the more team fights you will win.

Try that kind of strategy, and you just may see yourself having a bit more fun as you dare your opponents to dive you in all chat. :D

Well that comes down to Riots balancing approach, which is good. It's an approach that lets champions keep their strengths but enchances their weaknesses. For immobile champions, typically their immobility is their weakness. So when you enhance that weakness further, it does more damage to them than it would ever do to a mobile champion because aside from Kassadin, Riot almost never tones down mobility on a champion. Which could be good, it could be bad but perhaps they should really be careful with these nerfs to immobile champions and look for other ways to not punish them for being immobile. I highly doubt that will ever happen though.

Newer champions like Reksai and Gnar are extremely safe in toplane with their mobility and pokes, although Nidalee spear + run away cougar mode despite all of her many changes has still made her quite a risk adverse champion.  Although in a big massive team brawl, I'd rather have Mordekaiser than any of those three (mainly he does a lot of aoe damage and it goes all over the place).  Add Amumu aoe to the roster, and it is going to be a wrecking day, provided your team will back them up.  Of course a siege comp can spread out and pick them to pieces, so I suppose nothing is without counters.

There are some mechanics in league that are very powerful and stand above the others.  Mobility cannot be mathematically "weighed" in the same way that "damage" can be calculated, because a lot of it depends on where you are going *to* and *why*.  But in the hands of good player, the value of mobility is worth more than a player who uses mobility to just go anywhere for any reason.  It is hard to say that someone snowballed because of their mobility or if the other side just fed.  Even with the ambiguity though, it is a mecahnic I find cause for concern in champion power creep.

A more obvious mechanic is true damage (hello Ahri/Irelia).  But I think the TD champions are scrutinized a bit more carefully in that the presence of counters still exist.  Even still, they are quite in vogue.

Agreed. The mobility creep is getting more and more oppressive for immobile champions to the point you can't play them without gimping your team. Champions kit today are so overloaded it's just not fair. 

To compare, I'll take Teemo who was among the first 40 champions, so 2009, and Gnar who was released in 2014.

{{champion:17}}

- Good harass via poison during laning
- Move around the map quickly, but it disabled when hit by champions
- Blind protect against AA
- Mushrooms give decent additional map coverage and damage/slow

but then...

- Extremely squishy
- Does not scale very well with levels (main poison damage cap at level 9)
- Low AA range hurt him later in the game
- Lack hard CC
- Goes oom quickly

{{champion:150}} 

Mini Gnar alone brings

- Poke that can shred anyone thanks to % health damage
- Quick moving around the map
- Spammable slow if catching boomerang
- High safety and chasing potential thanks to quick jump and MS boost that synergize with his HP shred
- Manaless

Already, he does almost anything Teemo does better, but it does not end here since Gnar also...

- Scale extremely well into late game thanks to Mega Gnar and Mini Gnar AA range reaching Teemo's by level 18
- Can become insanely tanky
- Got loads of hard CC in addition to soft CC
- High base damage means he can build tanky and still do loads of damage

His only weakness is that he can't control his transformation, but it's still no excuse to give a champion such an overloaded kit.

It also happens that the champions I like to play ({{champion:17}} , {{champion:63}} , {{champion:111}} , {{champion:80}} and {{champion:86}}) are all immobile (well ok, Pant can go in, but not out) and I find it frustrating that I get "outkit" rather then "outskilled".

How the fuck am I supposed to beat Zed as Brand?

How the hell am I supposed to survive Gnar as Garen?

Riot may say that "hard counter" do not exist, but when you look at this, it's just not true.

So yeah, mobility and overloaded kit are really getting out of control.

Soft cc and movement speed have become increasingly irrelevant with releases of champions that have dashes.

I feel the same way with how the META has become. You don't get to have true fun with mage champs anymore because assassins that don't even have to rely on having movement speed because they have a dash, leap, blink, etc. and can close that gap without buying tier 2 boots, and can kill you quickly because they opted for damage instead of those boots, because they can. The META has become a lot less reliant on movement speed, and a lot more reliant on whether you have a dash or not. The last immobile champ that was released was Vel'Koz. Vel'koz has a good amount of slows and a decent knockup. Though soft cc is increasingly becoming less and less reliable, as movement speed is becoming less and less impactful. With the release of champions like Rek'Sai, slows have become almost useless for champs that have to peel. Peeling has become hard cc or no cc. Slows in general have suffered from many champ releases. Rek'Sai can easily escape or kill all squishies if all the champ has to offer is a slow. For instance Volibear, Skarner if his ultimate is down, and many other champions especially including many of the mages that rely on slows. Please consider this more with the champions to come, because it is shifting to how fast you can move while doing the most damage.
